headline: Snap, Google, Robinhood: Trending stocks
summary: Google's (GOOGL, GOOG) multibillion-dollar AI dealmaking spree continues, including a potential partnership with Apple (AAPL). SNAP stock pops on strong earnings, fueling hopes of a rebound. Robinhood (HOOD) shares turn red in pre-market. And as Hong Kong surpasses the NYSE and NASDAQ as the world's top listing venue, IPO's of autonomous driving firms Pony AI (PONY) and WeRide (WRD) nosedive on their debuts. For more live coverage of the markets, watch the full episode of Market Sunrise and visit Yahoo Finance.

For more live coverage of the markets, watch the full episode of Market Sunrise and visit Yahoo Finance.

headline: AppLovin Reports Strong Earnings. The Stock Is Up.
summary: AppLovin  reported strong third-quarter earnings results Wednesday afternoon.  Earnings per share were $2.45, above Wall Street’s consensus estimate of $2.38, and up from $1.29 last year.  Its profit margin for the third quarter was a little soft at 59.5%, against a Wall Street consensus of 62.1%.

content.title: AppLovin Reports Strong Earnings. The Stock Is Up.
content.summary: AppLovin  reported strong third-quarter earnings results Wednesday afternoon.  Earnings per share were $2.45, above Wall Street’s consensus estimate of $2.38, and up from $1.29 last year.  Its profit margin for the third quarter was a little soft at 59.5%, against a Wall Street consensus of 62.1%.

headline: ‘Jenga Tower’ US Economy Teeters as Middle Class Pulls Back Spending
summary: This dichotomy between the haves and have-nots isn’t new, but the economic strain is now bleeding from the lowest earners to the middle class, creating an even starker divide that some economists say makes the economy more susceptible to a downturn.  The richest 10% of households are fueling nearly half of total US spending, thanks to a stock market surge that has boosted wealth and in turn propelled economic output this year.  Meanwhile, lower-income families are pulling back in the face of tight budgets, still-high living costs and a raft of corporate layoffs.

content.title: ‘Jenga Tower’ US Economy Teeters as Middle Class Pulls Back Spending
content.summary: This dichotomy between the haves and have-nots isn’t new, but the economic strain is now bleeding from the lowest earners to the middle class, creating an even starker divide that some economists say makes the economy more susceptible to a downturn.  The richest 10% of households are fueling nearly half of total US spending, thanks to a stock market surge that has boosted wealth and in turn propelled economic output this year.  Meanwhile, lower-income families are pulling back in the face of tight budgets, still-high living costs and a raft of corporate layoffs.
